text:
@Rufus 
Leaving pay check to pay check it reflects people's ability to prioritize or manage their money. If they chose to spend it all then you live pay check to pay check. But look around... every grown up and every child holds a smart phone in his/her hand. Every family has at least 2 tv sets in their house and cable tv which is around $150/month.
Most families have a play station. Go to restaurants, especially on Friday and Saturday, and see a line of people at the doors waiting to be seated. And most of those people are families with 2-3 children.
When I had a very low income, cable was not an option for me, I cooked my food, I did not need 10 pairs of shoes in my closet and another new pair every month etc etc and I still saved some money for emergency situations. It's up to people to manage their money with maturity if they don't like living pay check to pay check. Also, getting better qualification at work helps to get promotions and raises salary.

In a Beijing ballroom, Kushner family pushes $500,000 ‚Äòinvestor visa‚Äô to wealthy Chinese

The Kushner family came to the United States as refugees, worked hard and made it big ‚Äî and if you invest in Kushner properties, so can you.

That was the message delivered Saturday by White House senior adviser Jared Kushner‚Äôs sister Nicole Kushner Meyer to a ballroom full of wealthy Chinese investors in Beijing.

Over several hours of slide shows and presentations, representatives from the Kushner¬†family business urged Chinese citizens gathered at a Ritz-Carlton hotel to consider investing hundreds of thousands of dollars in a New Jersey luxury apartment complex that would help them¬†secure what‚Äôs known as an investor visa.

The potential investors were advised to invest sooner rather than later in case visa rules change¬†under the Trump administration.¬†‚ÄúInvest early, and you will invest under the old rules,‚Äù one speaker said.

text: @Carlos Carlos I completely agree with you, it's a shame and it would be nice if it could change. However, the American paycheck isn't ready for US products on a mass scale yet. I'm not thinking about myself here; I have enough money to be able to afford those things. I'm thinking about my neighbors and friends in lower income areas. I think the smarter way to approach this would be to incentivize American production FIRST, and then make international products more expensive by imposing higher tariffs. Otherwise the only thing that will happen is that we pay more for Chinese goods which are still cheaper than American goods. The 1980's didn't deal with post recession issues the way we do today, and people had more money in their pockets during that time. Let's not go back in time and make the same mistakes again. let's move forward and make our economy and society better.

text:
‚Äã Granny Gums  ,

 The biggest "red flag" that we might be heading into a recession is the inversion of the Yield Curve (long-term vs short-term government bonds). 

 After that, you have a decline in manufacturing jobs, rising consumer price index, declining consumer confidence index, rising oil prices, and overall global economic decline over the past few years.  Throw in a needless trade war or two, global economic effects of Brexit, and possibly another pointless government shutdown, and yeah, we could be looking at a recession by this time next year.



Nobody can predict the future, but the yield curve indicator has caught the attention of many investors.

text:
--Trump's Tariffs are Effecting our Recycling and its beginning to cost Americans a lot of money and increasing our pollution.  China is no longer buying our recyclables.  

--Is this the end of recycling? 
https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/markets/is-this-the-end-of-recycling/ar-BBUpk8p?li=BBnb7Kz&ocid=mailsignout

--These municipalities have two choices: pay much higher rates to get rid of recycling, or throw it all away.

--Most are choosing the latter. ‚ÄúWe are doing our best to be environmentally responsible, but we can‚Äôt afford it,‚Äù said Judie Milner, the city manager of Franklin, New Hampshire. Since 2010, Franklin has offered curbside recycling and encouraged residents to put paper, metal, and plastic in their green bins. When the program launched, Franklin could break even on recycling by selling it for $6 a ton. Now, Milner told me, the transfer station is charging the town $125 a ton to recycle, or $68 a ton to incinerate. One-fifth of Franklin‚Äôs residents live below the poverty line, and the city government didn‚Äôt want to ask them to pay more to recycle, so all those carefully sorted bottles and cans are being burned. Milner hates knowing that Franklin is releasing toxins into the environment, but there‚Äôs not much she can do. ‚ÄúPlastic is just not one of the things we have a market for,‚Äù she said.

text:
Kushners‚Äô China Deal Flop Was Part of Much Bigger Hunt for Cash

Jared Kushner,¬†Donald Trump‚Äôs son-in-law and top adviser, wakes up each morning to a growing problem that will not go away. His family‚Äôs real estate business,¬†Kushner Cos., owes hundreds of millions of dollars on a 41-story office building on Fifth Avenue. It has failed to secure foreign investors, despite an extensive search, and its resources are more limited than generally understood. As a result, the company faces significant challenges.

Over the past two years, executives and family members have sought substantial overseas investment from previously undisclosed places: South Korea‚Äôs sovereign-wealth fund, France‚Äôs richest man, Israeli banks and insurance companies, and exploratory talks with a Saudi developer, according to former and current executives. These were in addition to previously reported¬†attempts¬†to raise money in China and Qatar.

text:
--Trump‚Äôs Trade War With China Makes Russia Great Again
https://www.cfr.org/blog/trumps-trade-war-china-makes-russia-great-again

--‚ÄúTariffs will make our country much richer than it is today,‚Äù President Trump tweeted in August. So far, there‚Äôs not much evidence of that. As the left-hand graphic above shows, U.S. exports to China have plummeted since June‚Äîwhile U.S. imports from China have continued to rise. Meanwhile, U.S. importers (many of whom are exporters) have seen their U.S. tariff bill more than double since May, topping $5 billion in October.  

--Trump‚Äôs tariff war has some clear winners, however‚Äîhigh among them, Russia. As shown in the left-hand graphic, Chinese imports from non-U.S. firms have continued to grow at a robust 18 percent year-over-year rate while those from U.S. firms have fallen. Among the hardest-hit U.S. sectors have been soybeans, autos, and oil. Whereas China had accounted for about 22 percent of U.S. oil exports in the two years to July 2018, it fell to zero thereafter. This has proven a boon to alternative suppliers like Russia, as shown in the right-hand figure. And so, in the ultimate irony, Americans are paying tariffs that boost the profits of Russian firms subject to U.S. sanctions.

Trump Lies Again About ‚ÄòChina Paying Tariffs‚Äô To The U.S. Treasury
The president‚Äôs threat to raise tariffs on Chinese goods would hit American consumers, not China.
https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-lies-china-paying-tariffs-to-usa_n_5ccf8704e4b0e4d757347bda

Economists have estimated that the trade war is costing the U.S. more than $3 billion a month.
A University of Chicago study found that consumers paid an extra $1.5 billion for washing machines last year because of a Trump tariff imposed at the behest of Whirpool Corp. that only added $82 million to U.S. coffers. That was because manufacturers got away with charging more for dryers along with washing machines, even though no tariffs were added to the cost of dryers.

text:
CNN is guilty. 

18 U.S. Code ¬ß‚ÄØ2385. Advocating overthrow of Government reads:

Whoever knowingly or willfully advocates, abets, advises, or teaches the duty, necessity, desirability, or propriety of overthrowing or destroying the government of the United States or the government of any State, Territory, District or Possession thereof, or the government of any political subdivision therein, by force or violence, or by the assassination of any officer of any such government; or
Whoever, with intent to cause the overthrow or destruction of any such government, prints, publishes, edits, issues, circulates, sells, distributes, or publicly displays any written or printed matter advocating, advising, or teaching the duty, necessity, desirability, or propriety of overthrowing or destroying any government in the United States by force or violence, or attempts to do so; or
Whoever organizes or helps or attempts to organize any society, group, or assembly of persons who teach, advocate, or encourage the overthrow or destruction of any such government by force or violence; or becomes or is a member of, or affiliates with, any such society, group, or assembly of persons, knowing the purposes thereof‚Äî
Shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than twenty years, or both, and shall be ineligible for employment by the United States or any department or agency thereof, for the five years next following his conviction.
If two or more persons conspire to commit any offense named in this section, each shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than twenty years, or both, and shall be ineligible for employment by the United States or any department or agency thereof, for the five years next following his conviction.
As used in this section, the terms ‚Äúorganizes‚Äù and ‚Äúorganize‚Äù, with respect to any society, group, or assembly of persons, include the recruiting of new members, the forming of new units, and the regrouping or expansion of existing clubs, classes, and other units of such society, group, or assembly of persons.

What a bloody moron. China isn't paying anything for these tariffs Trump is enacting - America is. The American people, American businesses. Trump is playing games with our wallets, not Chinese ones. It's clear he has never done any kind of payment or cost calculation himself, because he clearly has no idea how tariffs work. Who pays those 10-25% extra for the same goods? We do.

Hundreds of small and mid-sized American businesses in my production trade has gone under already, because of this - because there is no American alternative to the materials we need (at least not one we can afford), our profit margin is smaller than the tariffs, and passing those cost increases onto our customers meant we were no longer able to compete. Only way we could habe survived under Trump's tariffs would have been to cut worker wages all the way down to below minimum wage, and that is absolutely not an option.

text: @MLK's Conservative Ghost The stock market and GDP are not good indicators of how well the economy is doing for average Americans. Unemployment is relatively low, but as Trump has pointed out in the past, the unemployment rate doesn't account for those who have stopped looking for work. The labor force has shrunk by proportion of the population even as the unemployment rate falls. The middle class is shrinking as the gap between the rich and poor continues to widen. More than 40 percent of Americans can't afford basic necessities like rent and food. Most Americans aren't saving enough for retirement, nearly half will retire broke. Americans owe more money than ever, and most are currently in debt. Americans born into poverty are more likely than ever before to stay that way. Almost 20% of Americans, or more than 40 million adults, can't afford or access needed healthcare. Jobs are being shipped overseas at an even faster rate than before. Wages remain stagnant while the cost of living continues to grow. The housing market right now is reminiscent of the 2006 bubble and ready to burst. Economists are predicting another downturn soon.

text: @Ver Coda First of all before we start I want to say 2 things. Not everything Trump says or does I necessarily agree with. 10%-20% of the stuff he says or does I can't defend him on. Ex: What Trump said about John McCain (Not a war hero because he was captured), the birther movement about Barack Obama's birth certificate, he talks about bringing back manufacturing jobs to the U.S., yet his products are manufactured in other countries (Hypocrisy), he's against illegal immigration and yet he has exploited illegal aliens for cheap labor in his organizations (hypocrisy), his affair with a pornstar, bump stock ban and windmills cause cancer etc. There are 2 things that I can and cannot defend him on. The tariffs and the Hollywood access tape. What I didn't like about Trump's trade war is that it hurt the farmers. What I liked about the tariffs is that it did bring back the steel industry. Also, there's 1 country in particular who I support taxing: China. For years, China has been cheating on trade with the US. These are 2 harmful practices China has been using: IP theft and currency manipulation. Trump is trying to ensure fair trade. The Hollywood access tape I can sort of defend him on as well. When men are alone with their friends behind closed doors, their going to make sex jokes like that. Also, let's put his words into context, he said that when you're a star and you're famous, they let you do it (insinuating consent). If he said that he would grab women's crotches without consent, I would condemn it completely. He did apologize for his comments. I wouldn't have said grab them by the pussy if I were him. The reason why those 9 things don't bother me that much is because it doesn't influence any policy/campaign promises while he's in office. Second of all, I will not use fox news as a reference to back my claim. I don't watch fox news. I listen to left wing networks more than right wing networks simply because I like to be intellectually honest and listen to what the other side has to say. With that being said, let's begin.

text: @Ver Coda There are many reasons why an average person like me supports Trump. When you interview trump supporters about why they voted for him, they tell you things like this: He wants to lower taxes, he rejects globalism and puts America first, he wants to renegotiate better trade deals and bring back jobs for the American worker, he supports the 2A, he supports our veterans and wants to rebuild our badly depleted military etc. For me personally, there are 5 huge reasons why I like him: 1. He's an entrepreneur. 2. He's anti establishment. 3. He's against illegal immigration and wants to secure our borders. 4. He's honest about the threat of radical Islamic terrorism. 5. He's against the PC culture and speaks his mind.
